title: 103_s1952
content:
The United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995 provides specifications for the coin. The Secretary of the Treasury shall issue not more than 500,000 $1 silver coins, weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins shall feature a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States Botanic Garden, with inscriptions of the coin's value and the year 1995. The coins issued under this Act shall be legal tender, with inscriptions of the words "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". Legal tender status is provided in Section 5103 of Title 31, United States Code. The Secretary shall obtain silver for the coins minted under this Act only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design for the coins authorized by this Act shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design shall also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The issuance of coins under this Act is outlined. The issuance of coins under the Act includes the quality of coins minted, mint facility restrictions, and the period of issuance from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995. Additionally, the sale of coins is also addressed. The coins authorized under this Act shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, plus surcharge. Bulk sales will be available at a reasonable discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a discount before issuance of the coins. Bulk sales will be available at a reasonable discount. A surcharge of $10 per coin is required for all sales. General Waiver of Procurement Regulations: No law governing procurement or public contracts shall apply to the procurement of goods or services necessary for carrying out the provisions of this Act. Nothing in this section shall relieve any person entering into a contract under this Act from complying with any law relating to equal employment opportunity.

Distribution of Surcharges: All surcharges received by the Secretary from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be promptly paid by the Secretary to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden.

Audits: Audits will be conducted. The Comptroller General has the right to examine the books, records, documents, and other data of the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden related to expenditures. This Act is titled the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" and specifies coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 500,000 $1 coins with specific specifications including weight, diameter, and composition. The design of the coins will feature a rose and the United States Botanic Garden facade. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design will be selected in consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, struck at a single Mint facility, and issued between January 1, 1995, and December 31, 1995. The coins authorized under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be available at a discount, prepaid orders will be accepted with a discount, and all sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS.

No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity requirements.

SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

Surcharges from coin sales go to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden.

SEC. 9. AUDITS.

The Comptroller General can audit the National Fund's expenditures under section 8.
